review.title: On Choosing Committees Based on Approval Votes in the Presence of Outliers
review.abstract: We study the computational complexity of committee selection problem for several approval-based voting rules in the presence of outliers. Our first result shows that outlier consideration makes committee selection problem intractable for approval, net approval, and minisum approval voting rules. We then study parameterized complexity of this problem with five natural parameters, namely the target score, the size of the committee (and its dual parameter, the number of candidates outside the committee), the number of outliers (and its dual parameter, the number of non-outliers). For net approval and minisum approval voting rules, we provide a dichotomous result, resolving the parameterized complexity of this problem for all subsets of five natural parameters considered (by showing either FPT or W[1]-hardness for all subsets of parameters). For the approval voting rule, we resolve the parameterized complexity of this problem for all subsets of parameters except one.

metadata.title: On Choosing Committees Based on Approval Votes in the Presence of Outliers

sections.text: ar Xiv: 151 1.04 190v 1 [cs.M A] 1We also examine approximation algorithms for this problem. We show that there is no α (·) factor approximation algorithm for approval and net approval voting rules, for each calculable function α (·), unless P = NP. For the minisum voting rule, we provide a (1 + ε) factor approximation algorithm that runs in time nO (log m / ε2), for each constant ε > 0, where m and n are the number of candidates or the number of votes.

sections.heading: 1.1 Our Contributions
sections.text: The last two results, as originally defined in the literature, are designed simply to give us the total amount of approval that a committee receives from all voters. Therefore, the results themselves are not diminishing functions of n, and as such, the outlier issue is not interesting if we use the results directly (in particular, it is impossible to improve these results by removing votes). Therefore, we consider the dual scoring system that complements the original - namely, that we evaluate a committee based on the amount of rejection it receives from all votes, and try to minimize total rejection of the candidates. Typically, for each notion of approval, there are either one or two natural complementary notions of rejection that present themselves (discussed in more detail). This formulation is consistent with the idea that we want to capture our results "distance" rather than proximity.

sections.heading: 1.2 Related Work
sections.text: The notion of outliers is quite prominent in the literature relating to the next strings, where the usual setting is that we obtain n strings via any alphabet Σ, and the task is to find a stringx that minimizes either the maximum hamming distance from each string or the sum of hamming distances from all strings. In the context of the theory of social choice, the concept of outliers is closely related to manipulation and control of the election by removing voters and candidates [Bartholdi et al., 1992, Bartholdi III et al., 1989b, Conitzer et al., 2007, Chevaleyre et al., 2007, Hemaspaandra et al., 2007, Brandt et al., Faliszewski et al., 2009, Meir et al., 2008, Procaccia et al., al., 2007, Elkind et al., 2009, Betzler et Uhlmann, 2008].In the minimax notion of removal, the problem became the Boulier al.

sections.heading: 5 Approximation Results
sections.text: In this section, we describe our results in the context of approximation algorithms, where our goal is to minimize the target value, since the reject size m * and the budget n are given for the number of outliers as part of the input. In the first part, we focus on the minisum tuning rule and show an εm approximation algorithm for each constant ε > 0. In addition, we have a (1 + ε) approximation algorithm, whose runtime is nO (log m / ε2), for each constant ε > 0. Subsequently, we show that the target value for all tuning rules within a factor NP is difficult to approximate, since it is already NP-difficult to determine whether t = 0 is.

sections.heading: 5.1 Approximation Algorithms
sections.text: We now turn to some approximation algorithms for the Minisum-Outliers problem. Our first result is the following: Theorem 5. There is an approximation algorithm for the Minisum-Outliers problem (for each constant). Our next result is an approximation scheme with a subexponential runtime, loosely based on the framework introduced in [Lo et al., 2014]. For this purpose we will use the following lemma.Lemma 7. Let us be a positive constant. Then there is a subset of voices V, there is a subset V based on size O (logm).

sections.heading: 5.2 Hardness of Approximation
sections.text: In the previous section, we showed some approaches to approximating the target score in the context of the Minisum problem VR = VR problem. We now show that the other voting rules are inapproximable in a very strong sense. Our first hardness result is that it is NP-difficult to verify, even if there is a subset of outlier problems and a corresponding committee for which the net rejection is zero. (·) It follows that the net rejection is zero. (Unless the net rejection is zero.) It follows that P = NP.2, it is NP-difficult to verify, even if there is a subset of outlier problems and a corresponding committee for which the rejection is zero. To do this, we reduce a problem closely related to Max Clique, namely the determination of an optimal balance of two.

sections.heading: 6 Concluding Remarks and Future Directions
sections.text: We have investigated the problem of determining a committee that is good for a large portion of the electorate, based on some common voting rules. We start by showing that our choice of the term disapproval is an arbitrary one by pointing out the following problem. We use the notation disapproval to denote the voting rule given by the corresponding bottom row in Table 1.Lemma 9. There is a polynomial time approximation that results in a reduction of disapproval-outlier problem and vice-outlier problem. metadata.abstractText: We study the computational complexity of committee selection problem for several approval-based voting rules in the presence of outliers. Our first result shows that outlier consideration makes committee selection problem intractable for approval, net approval, and minisum approval voting rules. We then study parameterized complexity of this problem with five natural parameters, namely the target score, the size of the committee (and its dual parameter, the number of candidates outside the committee), the number of outliers (and its dual parameter, the number of non-outliers). For net approval and minisum approval voting rules, we provide a dichotomous result, resolving the parameterized complexity of this problem for all subsets of five natural parameters considered (by showing either FPT or W[1]-hardness for all subsets of parameters). For the approval voting rule, we resolve the parameterized complexity of this problem for all subsets of parameters except one. We also study approximation algorithms for this problem. We show that there does not exist any α(·) factor approximation algorithm for approval and net approval voting rules, for any computable function α(·), unless P = NP. For the minisum voting rule, we provide a (1 + ε) factor approximation algorithm running in time n log /ε2), for every constant ε > 0, where m and n are the number of candidates and the number of votes respectively.
